title: Effect of Citric Acid on Crab Metabolism

content.question:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

The red king crab, Paralithodes camtschaticus, inhabits shallow coastal waters in the northern Pacific Ocean that can vary in temperature from <math alttext="1 degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="13 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>13</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The body temperature of the crab is typically similar to that of the surrounding water. In order to study the effect of temperature on crab metabolism, scientists purified the enzyme phosphofructokinase (<math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) from red king crabs. <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> catalyzes a reaction early in the glycolysis pathway (Figure 1).

Figure 1. The conversion of fructose <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>phosphate (<math alttext="F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) to fructose <math alttext="1, 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1,6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>bisphosphate (<math alttext="F B P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FBP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

The scientists determined the rate of the <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-catalyzed reaction using a constant amount of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and increasing concentrations of the substrate <math alttext="F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. To determine whether the reaction rate is affected by the nucleotide <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the analyses were additionally performed in the presence of <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 2).

Figure 2. Effect of temperature and <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

In a second analysis of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity at different temperatures, the scientists determined how the concentration of citric acid in the reaction mixture affects the rate of the reaction at <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>5</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 3) in the presence of a constant amount of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Citric acid is the first metabolic intermediate produced by the Krebs cycle. All reactions were performed in the presence of <math alttext="1 millimolar F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Figure 3. Effect of citric acid on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. All reactions were carried out in the presence of <math alttext="1 millimolar F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Describe the transfer of energy that occurs in the reaction shown in Figure 1.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored.

The red king crab, Paralithodes camtschaticus, inhabits shallow coastal waters in the northern Pacific Ocean that can vary in temperature from <math alttext="1 degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="13 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>13</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The body temperature of the crab is typically similar to that of the surrounding water. In order to study the effect of temperature on crab metabolism, scientists purified the enzyme phosphofructokinase (<math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) from red king crabs. <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> catalyzes a reaction early in the glycolysis pathway (Figure 1).

Figure 1. The conversion of fructose <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>phosphate (<math alttext="F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) to fructose <math alttext="1, 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1,6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>bisphosphate (<math alttext="F B P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>FBP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

The scientists determined the rate of the <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-catalyzed reaction using a constant amount of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and increasing concentrations of the substrate <math alttext="F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. To determine whether the reaction rate is affected by the nucleotide <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the analyses were additionally performed in the presence of <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 2).

Figure 2. Effect of temperature and <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

In a second analysis of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activity at different temperatures, the scientists determined how the concentration of citric acid in the reaction mixture affects the rate of the reaction at <math alttext="5 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>5</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Figure 3) in the presence of a constant amount of <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Citric acid is the first metabolic intermediate produced by the Krebs cycle. All reactions were performed in the presence of <math alttext="1 millimolar F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Figure 3. Effect of citric acid on the rate of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="P F K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. All reactions were carried out in the presence of <math alttext="1 millimolar F 6 P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.5 millimolar A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 mM ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) Describe the transfer of energy that occurs in the reaction shown in Figure 1.

(b) Identify a dependent variable in the experiment shown in Figure 2. Based on the data shown in Figure 2, justify the use of the substrate <math alttext="F 6 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at a concentration of <math alttext="1 millimolar " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 mM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when the scientists performed the experiments shown in Figure 3. Based on data shown in Figure 2 for reactions performed in the absence of <math alttext="A M P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, describe the relative difference between the reaction rate at <math alttext="15 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>15</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when the concentration of <math alttext="F 6 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.3 millimolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.3 mM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> AND when the concentration of <math alttext="F 6 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>F6P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.8 millimolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.8 mM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Based on Figure 3, calculate the fold change in the reaction rate (how many times higher or lower the reaction rate is) at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>25</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> when the concentration of citric acid is increased from <math alttext="0 millimolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0 mM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="4.0 millimolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>4 mM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) State a null hypothesis for the experiments shown in Figure 3. The scientists claim that the concentration of citric acid in cells regulates the rate of glycolysis by the cells. Support the scientists' claim using biological principles and the data provided. Predict the effect on the active site of <math alttext="P F K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> if <math alttext="P F K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PFK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is maintained at <math alttext="75 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>75</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>20</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes prior to starting the reaction.

(d) Some aquatic organisms that live in cold environments similar to that of the crabs have multiple forms of certain enzymes that catalyze reactions at various temperatures. Explain how having multiple forms of the enzymes would contribute to the fitness of these organisms. Both adult and juvenile red king crabs can be found in ocean water of a different salinity and osmolarity than their body tissues are. Explain why it is important to the crabs that they can regulate the osmolarity of their tissues.
